value.text: The sky is the limit... Groups of the life

Everything together

Our lifespan, typically capped at just over 100 years (Steenstrup, Troels, et al., ), often presents challenges in conceptualizing vast spans of time. Moreover, the inability to perceive the unseen adds another layer of complexity, underscoring the importance of approaching this material with patience and care.

As inhabitants of this planet, our gaze upwards on a nightly basis reveals but a glimpse of the stars. Over millennia, these observations have shaped our understanding of the cosmos, with outdated notions like Ptolemaic geocentrism falling by the wayside as our knowledge advances (Jones, A. Raymond, ). Let's delve into some key discoveries:

  • The transition from geocentrism to heliocentrism prompts questions: Could the works of the Maragha observatory have influenced Nicolau Copérnico's heliocentric model? While debated, consensus remains elusive (Elshaikh, Eman M. ; Goddu, André., , pp. 5, 6). We do not have doubt that Nicolau Copérnico's showed that our planet is not the center of the universe, but rather orbits the Sun (Copernicus, Nicolaus, ).
  • Sir Isaac Newton's elucidation of planetary motion in subsequent centuries (Newton, Isaac, , pp. 401 - 510).
  • It was necessary centuries for Albert Einstein to expand our understanding about gravitation (Einstein Relativity Easy, ).
  • Edwin Hubble's revelation of an expanding universe (Hubble, Edwin, ).

Let's engage in a physical exercise to deepen our understanding of Hubble's work:

Practice 1: Expanding like the universe
Start by crossing your arms, reducing the space you occupy. Then, slowly begin to open them until they are fully extended.
Hubble observed a phenomenon similar to this in the universe.

The discovery of the universe's expansion (Bahcall, Neta A., ) led us to another significant realization: in the distant past, all observable matter was condensed into a singular point known as the singularity, followed by a monumental expansion event known as the "Big Bang" theory (Williams, Matt, ).

As the universe emerged from the singularity, it entered the Planck epoch, the initial phase of its existence. Subsequently, the first discernible entities, known as forces, began to appear (Williams, Matt, ).

At this juncture in our study, we are providing a broad overview and introducing the works of various scientists. For a deeper understanding of the Big Bang theory, we recommend watching presentations by Sabine Hossenfelder (Hossenfelder, Sabine, ), Dr. Rebecca Smethurst (Smethurst, Rebecca. ), Space Today (Sacani, Sérgio. ) and Quantum Fracture (QuantumFracture, ).

From the smallest to the biggest

The early stages of the universe were marked by considerable turbulence, hindering the formation of the smallest structures we now recognize (Williams, Matt, ). It took three minutes after the universe emerged from the singularity for the first nuclei to appear, while the formation of the first atoms took thousands of years (NASA, Universe). Our understanding of these entities is relatively recent:
  • Democritus was the first to conceptualize the atom as a minuscule entity (Stewart, Ken, ; Berryman, Sylvia, ).
  • John Dalton's groundbreaking scientific work laid the foundation for our understanding of atoms (Dalton, John, ; Stewart, Ken, )
  • J. J. Thomson's experimentation on Dalton's model revealed the existence of subatomic particles, such as the electron (New, Charlotte, ; Stewart, Knn, ).
  • Ernest Rutherford's experiments proposed a model reminiscent of the solar system, with a central nucleus and orbiting electrons (Rutherford, Ernest, ; Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia).
  • Niels Bohr introduced a model featuring atomic orbitals (Bohr, Niels, ; Stewart, Ken, )
  • Erwin Schrödinger proposed a equation that delivers the probability to find an atomic particle in a region (Schrödinger, Erwin, ; Stewart, Ken, ).

Philosophical atomNiels Bohr atomQuantum atom
Figure 1: Simplified representation of Hydrogen Atom with different models. The source code is available in GitHub of the project (History Tracers, )

Notice how we start with the concept of something small and immutable: the atom (Stewart, Ken, ). Over time, scientific inquiry refined this notion, cementing the atom's status as a fundamental building block (Dalton, John, ; Stewart, Ken, ). Decades later, we uncovered an even smaller realm within the atom (New, Charlotte, ; Stewart, Ken, ), leading to the identification of subatomic particles (Sutton, Christine). Our understanding of the smallest unit has evolved, yet the fundamental principle remains: matter progresses from the minute to the massive (NASA, Universe).

Similarly, our perception of the atom's structure has undergone a transformation. Referencing Figure 1, we initially conceived of the atom as indivisible, progressing to models featuring orbitals reminiscent of the solar system. Ultimately, we arrived at a nuanced understanding allowing for the approximate localization of electrons. Further elucidation awaits in forthcoming texts.

Star formation

The process of star formation did not commence immediately in the universe; it took millions of years for the first stars to appear (Yoshii, Yuzuru, et al., ). This delay was due to the insufficient matter available to form massive dust clouds. However, when these clouds collapse, they give rise to dense and hot nuclei capable of fusing hydrogen (H) atoms into helium atoms (He) — the very fuel of stars (NASA, Stars). It's important to note that not all the mass within dust clouds undergoes this transformation; some remains as planetary material, comets, or persists as dust (NASA, Stars). For a deeper understanding, we recommend watching PBS and Space Today videos (PBS/NASA, ; Sacani, Sérgio, ).

Throughout a star's lifespan, small atoms undergo fusion processes, transforming into larger atoms. However, not all known atoms are synthesized within stars. The formation of atoms is closely tied to the size of the star. The largest element produced within stars is iron (Penovich, Kipp, Smoot et al.), while other elements are formed during cataclysmic events known as supernovae (Hajian, Allie et al.).

The formation of stars ultimately gives rise to larger groupings known as galaxies (NASA, Universe).

Conclusion

Entities that can be assembled, grouped, have been emerging in the universe since the earliest moments after its departure from the singularity. These formations have evolved from the smallest particles to colossal structures. In our next session, we will delve further into the formations that facilitated the emergence of life.

text.question: Do the universe always had the size we observe?
text.additionalInfo: For a period of time, the idea of a static universe dominated over other hypotheses. However, Edwin Hubble's measurements, followed by others, confirmed that the universe is expanding.

text.question: First the matter we cannot see appear, the atoms, and later the matter we see appeared. Is this sentence correct?
text.additionalInfo: The observable structures in the universe are formed from smaller groupings of matter; thus, everything we see is organized from the smallest to the largest.

text.question: Everything we see comes from a unique place, the singularity, is it possible to say: I have something different of other people?
text.additionalInfo: Some people mistakenly consider themselves different from others, but everything shares the same origin, whether it’s other humans, other animals, or any other matter around us.
